en.slide1_1: Hey! I'm Lana the potion master. You and my assistant Pebbles will be preparing some nice potions
en.slide1_2: But first, we need to know some useful concepts
en.slide1_3: All matter is made from atoms. Individual atoms can combine with other atoms to form molecules
en.slide1_4: Atoms and molecules are always in constant motion
en.slide1_5: Everything we can see and touch is made up of matter. Matter exists in three main forms: solids, liquids, and gases
en.slide1_6: There's also the plasma state and has certain properties that other states does not have
en.slide1_7: Every state of matter has different properties
en.slide1_8: Let's see if we can use some of this properties to create some potions!
en.slide2_1: In a liquid, particles of matter move relative to one another but remain in contact
en.slide2_2: The movement of the particles causes the liquid to be variable in shape
en.slide2_3: Liquids will flow and fill the lowest portion of a container, taking on the shape of the container but not changing in volume
en.slide2_4: We can see this behaviour when the fluid runs through the pipes and container and takes the shape of them
en.slide3_1: Gas is a state of matter that has no fixed shape and no fixed volume
en.slide3_2: Gases also take the shape of their container, but they are much lighter than liquids
en.slide3_3: What distinguishes a gas from liquids and solids is the vast separation of the individual gas particles
en.slide3_4: That means they will expand to fill any container they are placed in
en.slide3_5: Within a gas, atoms and molecules are far apart from one another and bounce around independently
en.slide3_6: They do not flow around one another as in a liquid, but rather ping off each other freely in all directions
en.slide4_1: State is an extrinsic property of  matter that depends on physical conditions like temperature and pressure
en.slide4_2: When a substance changes from solid to liquid or gas, its atoms and molecules begin to move relative to each other
en.slide4_3: When it changes from liquid or gas to solid, its atoms and molecules stop moving relative to each other
en.slide4_4: Water is a perfect example, if you add high temperature, it's molecules will losen and water will be in gas state
en.slide4_5: If you add low temperature to the water, it's molecules cannot move freely and water will be in solid state
en.slide4_6: If you add low temperature to evaporated water, the molecules will be less losen, but they can still move and slide past another
en.slide4_7: We can see the last behaviour when we use the condenser, where the vapor is condensed to water
en.tutorial_0: Redirect the liquid through the pipes to fill the glass container!

en.tutorial2_1: We got a new piece, the BURNER!
en.tutorial2_2: The burner generates very high temperature inside of it
en.tutorial2_3: If water pass through it, it will evaporate very quickly
en.tutorial2_4: We can use it to bring vapors to the glass container
en.tutorial3_1: We got a new piece, the CONDENSER!
en.tutorial3_2: The condenser has a very low temperature inside of it
en.tutorial3_3: If vapor pass through it, it will be condensed and return to liquid state
en.tutorial3_4: Be careful! It will freeze water!
